ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: No, unless you think it will be particularly helpful for your senior essay, grad school application, or career prospects. Molleen is dedicated and enthusiastic but not a good professor. If you are not totally obsessed with minimal or conceptual art, a lot of the discussions will be painful.
If you're interested in the material, absolutely - unbelievable opportunities, fascinating material and discussion.

Yes, if you are interested in American art from the second half of the twentieth century, this is a good course to take. If you don't know much about the topic beforehand, it might not be as rewarding for you-- though this is the problem (tradeoff) with seminars in general. Molleen made the course very interesting and fun, though!

Yes, I would. I think that this was a fun class, though the friday afternoon was difficult sometimes, and I learned a lot. The readings were great. I do wish that we had discussed the readings in more depth. I feel like I only got a surface takeaway. But Molleen is great, really down to earth but also smart and knowledgeable. And so few classes in the art history department seem to be about post-modern art that this was a breath of fresh air.

Great class, one of the few classes on contemporary art at yale. You read a lot of artists texts and really interesting critical texts on the art, and write one short paper and one long research paper on a topic of your choice.
